conclusion: Both objects start from the same location and move in the same direction with velocity as a function of time.
Object A accelerates initially as its tangent line slopes upward, then decelerates as the slope decreases.
Object B also accelerates initially but at a different rate and then decelerates.
Relative velocity affects their distance apart; greatest relative velocity implies moving apart the fastest.
At t2, velocities of both objects intersect, indicating they have the same velocity.
Before t2, Object A moves faster than Object B, causing them to move apart.
After t2, Object B moves faster than Object A, causing them to come closer.
At t1, Object A is accelerating, and Object B is still accelerating but at a different rate.
At t3, both objects are decelerating, but the rate is different.
Distance between them changes according to their relative velocities.
Greatest distance apart occurs when relative velocity is greatest, met at t3.
The two objects are farthest apart at t3.
